title: Supporting Hyperactive Kids with Math Learning
description: Strategies for helping energetic, can't-sit-still kids succeed with math practice.
imageAlt: Active child finding ways to learn math

content.intro: "He can't sit still for 5 minutes!" Sound familiar? High-energy kids aren't broken – they just need different approaches to math learning.

sections.text: Some kids have more energy than others. Some have ADHD. Some are just young. Regardless of the reason, traditional "sit still and focus" math practice doesn't work for them.
The goal isn't to make them sit still. It's to find ways to learn that work WITH their energy, not against it.
Burn energy first. 5-10 minutes of running, jumping, or active play BEFORE practice. A tired body can focus better.
Instead of one 15-minute session, try three 5-minute sessions throughout the day. Matches their attention span.
"Do 3 problems, then 10 jumping jacks, then 3 more." Built-in movement keeps them going longer.

faq.question: Is my child just lazy or actually ADHD?
faq.answer: Only a professional can diagnose ADHD. But kids with ADHD often WANT to focus and can't – they're not choosing to be distracted. If effort doesn't help, consider evaluation.

faq.question: Should screen time count as rest for an active kid?
faq.answer: Screens aren't true rest – they stimulate the brain. Physical play is better for burning energy than switching from learning screen to entertainment screen.

faq.question: Will they grow out of it?
faq.answer: Some naturally become less physically hyperactive with age. Others have ADHD that persists. Either way, learning strategies that work WITH their energy serves them for life.
